_prev_prog_3.MD_OtherType: ALARMS IN ENGINE ROOMS AND ADJACENT HALLWAYS

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
1. Accidental release prevention and emergency response policies

ConAgra Poultry Company - Gainesville is committed to both the safety of our employees and that of the surrounding public, including both human health and the environment.  Safety is ensure through careful prevention measures and emergency planning.  The intent of our Prevention Program is the minimiation of all risks that could possibley lead to an accidental release.  This program focuses primarily on the mechanical integrity of the process equipment and the training of its operators.  The EmergencyAction Plan focuses on minimizing the potential impacts of an accidental release.  This is done by coordinating emergency actions with the Gainesville Fire Department and ensureing that employees are trained on the proper repsonse to and emergency situation.

2. The stationary source and regulated substances handled

ConAgra Poultry Company - Gainesville is a poultry processing plant.  The regulated substance handled at this plant is ammonia.  Ammonia is used as a regrigerant in the plant cooler and freezer system.  The mazimum quantity of ammonia stored at this facility is 42,500 pounds.

3. The worst-case release scenario and the alternative release scenario, including administrative controls and mitigation measures to limit the distances for each reported scenario

Worst-Case Scenario - Faliure of the high pressure receiver for the old side (south) engine room when filled to the greatest amount allowed would release 8,300 pounds of ammonia.  Company policy limits the maximum filling capacity of this vessel to 60%.  It is assumed that the entire contents are released as vapor over a ten minute time span and are subjected to a wind speed of 1.5 m/s with a stability class of F.  The distance to the toxic endpoint for the worst-case is 1.1 miles.
Alternative Scenario - The lifting of a pressure relief valve on the ammonia storage vessel for the new side (north) engine room.  Relief valves allow the escape

of ammonia at a total flow rate of 234 lbs/min.  Weather conditions are assumed to be average values of 3 m/s wind speed and stability class D.  The valves are assumed to be open 75% of the time during the release as the pressure builds and is relieved.  The distance to this endpoint is 0.2 miles and extends beyond the facility boundary.

4. The general accidental release prevention program and the specific prevention steps

ConAgra Poultry Company believes that the best way to prevent an accidental release is by being proactive in its approach to safety.  The facility maintains information about the proper use of its equipment and the possible hazards.  By following set operating procedures and maintenance routines, the process equipment within the facility will continue to operate in optimum condition.  Additionally, the release prevention program is constatnly being improved by sustained employee training and regular compliance audits.  Compliance with all applicable state codes and regulations ensure the contined safety of ConAgra.

5.  Five-year accident history

ConAgra Poultry Company - Ginesville facility has not experienced any accidents withing the last five years that either led to a significant release of hazardous chemicals or had the potential to lead to such a release.

6. The emergency action plan

A well planned emergency action plan can make a trementdous difference in the potential impacts of an accidental release.  Swift, efficient actions can minimized the damage to both human population and the natural surroundings.  To this end, ConAgra Poultry Company - Gainesville has coordinated emergency response efforts with the Gaines ville Fire Dept. and has instructed employees on the proper actions to take in the event of and accidental release.

7.  Planned changes to improve safety

Several items are presently being implemented by ConAgra Poultry Company - Gainesville to improve safety including hire new security personnel, implement new Lockout/Tag
out programs, add sprinkler systems, and conduct additional training.
